title: 107_s1414
content: The "Parent and Teacher Achievement Act of 2001" is cited in Section 1. Section 2 introduces state incentives for teacher testing and merit pay under Title II of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. The Secretary will award funds to states that administer tests to teachers every 3 to 5 years, have a merit-based compensation system, and require teachers to earn continuing education credits for recertification. The available funding is 50% of the excess funds appropriated for Title II, with limitations on total appropriations and state eligibility. For fiscal year 2001, funds are available under specific conditions, with limitations on total appropriations and state eligibility. States can use the funds for activities outlined in section 2207. The term 'State' refers to all 50 states and the District of Columbia. The effective date for the amendments is October 1, 2001. The text discusses the use of Federal education funds for teacher testing and merit pay, as well as a nonrefundable credit for elementary and secondary school expenses. The definitions of elementary and secondary schools are also provided. The text discusses a nonrefundable credit for elementary and secondary education expenses, with limitations on the maximum credit and tuition expenses per qualifying student. A qualifying student is defined as a dependent or relative enrolled in school on a full-time basis. A qualifying student, defined as a dependent or relative enrolled full-time in school, can receive a nonrefundable credit for education expenses. No double benefit is allowed, and taxpayers can elect to not apply the credit for a taxable year. The amendments made by this section provide a credit for contributions for the benefit of elementary and secondary schools, effective for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2001. The amendments provide a tax credit for qualified charitable contributions to school tuition organizations. The credit is 75% of the contributions for individuals, up to $500 ($1,000 for joint returns), and up to $100,000 for corporations. The tax credit is available for cash contributions to a school tuition organization that allocates at least 90% of its income to scholarships for elementary and secondary school students eligible for free or reduced-cost lunch. The scholarships must be for education up to 12th grade and are excludable from gross income. The term 'elementary and secondary school scholarship' refers to scholarships for education up to 12th grade that are excludable from gross income. Special rules include denial of double benefit, limitations on credit application, and treatment of controlled groups. Taxpayers can elect to have the credit not apply. The term 'elementary and secondary school scholarship' refers to scholarships for education up to 12th grade that are excludable from gross income. Special rules include denial of double benefit, limitations on credit application, and treatment of controlled groups. Taxpayers can elect to have the credit not apply. All persons treated as one employer under certain sections shall be treated as 1 taxpayer for purposes of this section. A taxpayer may elect to have this section not apply for any taxable year. The section provides a credit for contributions benefiting elementary and secondary schools, effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2001. Another credit is given to teachers who provide classroom materials under a new section. The tax code allows eligible educators to claim a credit for qualified elementary and secondary education expenses up to $1,000 per year. Eligible educators are defined as teachers, instructors, counselors, principals, or aides who work at least 900 hours in a school year. Qualified expenses include books, supplies, computer equipment, and supplementary materials used in the classroom. The tax code allows eligible educators to claim a credit for qualified elementary and secondary education expenses, such as books, supplies, computer equipment, and supplementary materials used in the classroom. No double benefit is allowed, and the credit cannot exceed the regular tax for the year minus other credits. Taxpayers can elect to not apply for the credit in a taxable year. The tax code provides a credit for elementary and secondary school teachers who supply classroom materials. The amendments apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2001. Adjusted gross income considers professional development expenses for teachers. The tax code now allows deductions for professional development expenses of elementary and secondary school teachers, up to $1,500, for participating in approved courses related to their curriculum or students. A deduction shall be allowed for expenses exceeding certain amounts for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2001.
